title: Sense-Making: Frustrations and Definitions
mainTopics: IETF 'rough consensus and running code' model
OGM as salon vs sense-making space

frustrations.description: Jerry asked participants to share frustrations with sense-making
examples: Lack of shared context due to filter bubbles (Eric in chat)
Pervasive disinformation - people actively preventing sense-making (Mike)
Need for complete consensus allows one person to hold all hostage (Mike)
Starting at Chapter 3 or 4, not fundamentals (Doug)
'Collective' as problematic aggregation that doesn't exist (Doug)
OGM hasn't done much sense-making, just salon conversations (Jerry)
Not clear what we mean by 'sense' (Gil)
No thread or objective, solution-oriented people get lost (Alex)

definingS ense.description: Gil's fundamental challenge: What do we mean by 'sense'?
gilQuestions: Does sense mean interpretation of reality satisfying to me?
Does it mean shared commitment to action, consent, decisions, coordination?
Most conversation seems about goals/decision-making - is that a subset?
Premature attention to goals implies tacit sense-making already happened
definingS ense.marcAntoineResponse: We're negotiating shared meaning right now - that's the process
definingS ense.kenHomerResponse: Expansive, exponentially synthetic definitions vs reductive final definitions

ietfModel.description: Mike Nelson's ideal: Internet Engineering Task Force process
elements: Rough consensus and running code (not complete consensus)
Humming instead of voting - anonymous technical judgment
People hum for best technical solution even if it doesn't help their company
Need goal AND deadline or higher power pushing toward consensus
ietfModel.context: Mike's experience negotiating at US Congress and UN (World Summit on Information Society, Internet Governance Forum)

collectiveIntelligence.description: Frameworks for collective vs individual sense-making

johnKellyContinuum.positive: Discover something novel none of you saw - collaboration breakthrough
johnKellyContinuum.negative: 95% agree but only come up with tiny 5% motherhood statement
johnKellyContinuum.aiPossibility: AI can identify themes you're not seeing that connect you

marcAntoineInsights: World more complex than any one person - need diversity of perspectives
Must empathize and understand other standpoints
Must go from map-making to decision-making
Sense-making happens in practice, in action together
collectiveIntelligence.dougCritique: Anything modified by 'collective' posits aggregate that doesn't exist, sets up for failure

goalsAndProcess.description: Tension between having goals/deadlines vs open exploration
goalsAndProcess.mikeNelson: Desperately need deadline or higher power pushing toward consensus
goalsAndProcess.gilFriend: Premature attention to goals can get in the way of sense-making
goalsAndProcess.marcAntoine: Sometimes you don't have common goal to start with, negotiating goal may be part of process
goalsAndProcess.alexKladitis: Solution-oriented, couldn't find thread without objective
goalsAndProcess.pattern: Process-oriented people (Marc-Antoine, Ken, Jerry) vs outcome-oriented (Alex, Mike)

kenHomerExample.context: Yosemite National Park workshop on conflict, 35 people
kenHomerExample.method: 400+ words/phrases about 'conflict' on post-its, arranged by bothersomeness
kenHomerExample.insight: 'Organ failure' = conflict so bad might have heart attack
kenHomerExample.result: Expansive shared meaning vs reductive definition
kenHomerExample.principle: Let everyone say what they think, don't nail down to fine definition

marcAntoine: We're always arguing about words because we're arguing with words
Negotiating shared meaning so we can have connection, communication, community
Praxis of thinking with others - learning to listen, see other perspectives
Don't expect formal definition to emerge or be agreed on
Illusion of consensus is terrible - we think we mean same thing, we don't
sharedMeaningVsDefinitions.rickBotelho: Need Weick's definition of sense-making as grounding, then critique where you differ
sharedMeaningVsDefinitions.alexKladitis: Not academic, more practical - you say this, you mean that
sharedMeaningVsDefinitions.jerryMichalski: Should have started with a couple definitions, might have helped

ogmReflection.jerryConcern: Very nice salon conversations, occasionally connect people, occasionally new ideas, but haven't done much sense-making
ogmReflection.mikeResponse: Several of us have used wisdom of this crowd to write very good stuff - look at broader ecosystem you've engendered
ogmReflection.gilResponse: I don't come to OGM for sense-making (so carry on)

storiesShared.topic: World Summit on Information Society - UN sense-making failure
storiesShared.summary: 20+ years ago in Geneva/Tunis. No common goal: US wanted human rights in cyberspace, China wanted to water down UN Human Rights Declaration, Tehran/Syria guys just wanted expense-paid weeks in Geneva. Supposed to have 3 meetings, stretched to 5 by constant objections. Complete consensus requirement allowed 1-2 people to hold all hostage.
storiesShared.impact: Example of sense-making failure when goals misaligned and bad process

storiesShared.summary: Belgium has ~52 Trappist and abbey beers brewed by monks. Mike's lifetime goal to narrow to top 4. Some only available at monastery, some no longer made. 'Ecumenical - will drink anything that's good.'
storiesShared.impact: Lighthearted opening, passion and lifetime goals

storiesShared.summary: 35 people, 400+ words for conflict, arranged by bothersomeness. 'Organ failure' = so bad might have heart attack. After seeing it, everyone included it in their understanding of conflict.
storiesShared.impact: Example of expansive shared meaning vs reductive definition

storiesShared.topic: Last week's poem (Afraid So) - wife's reaction
storiesShared.summary: Alex loved poem, sent to wife and kids. Kids said 'great poem.' Wife said 'that's not a poem.'
storiesShared.impact: Perfect illustration of different interpretations/definitions (Gil: 'Then it did its job')

frameworks.name: IETF Rough Consensus and Running Code
elements: Humming instead of voting for anonymity
Overwhelming loud hum vs minor dissenting hum = rough consensus
Engineers hum for best technical solution even against company interest

frameworks.name: Divergence Before Convergence
frameworks.description: Cannot converge if haven't explored, negotiated, empathized with other standpoints first

frameworks.name: Expansive vs Reductive Definitions
frameworks.description: Let everyone contribute to shared meaning, don't reduce to single definition - exponentially synthetic

frameworks.name: Weick's Sense-Making
frameworks.description: Need grounding definition to critique against, understand where differences lie

frameworks.name: Jazz Improv as Sense-Making
frameworks.description: Communication and perhaps sense-making without words

questionsRaised: What is evidence that sense-making has happened?
Has OGM done sense-making or just salon conversations?
Can we have a call without words?
How do we balance goals/deadlines with open exploration?
How do we avoid illusion of consensus while still coordinating?
What's the difference between collective intelligence and crowdsourcing?
How do solution-oriented people participate in process-oriented discussions?

resourcesShared.name: Untapped
resourcesShared.description: Beer rating app, never drink substandard beer anywhere

resourcesShared.name: Vivino
resourcesShared.description: Wine app - take picture of label, auto-identifies vineyard and year

resourcesShared.name: Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF)
resourcesShared.description: Standards body using 'rough consensus and running code'

resourcesShared.name: World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS)
resourcesShared.about: UN attempt to scope role in digital future - failed sense-making

resourcesShared.name: Internet Governance Forum (IGF)
resourcesShared.about: UN system - worked better because deadline and concrete deliverables

resourcesShared.name: COP (Conference of the Parties)
resourcesShared.concern: Many there on expense accounts, not for purpose

poems.title: A Note Passed to Superman
poems.author: Lucille Clifton
poems.opening: Sweet Jesus, Superman! If I'd seen you, dressed in your blue suit, I would have known you.
poems.closing: You can trust me. There is no planet stranger than the one I'm from.
poems.groupReaction: Jerry: 'Beautiful. And that made perfect sense to everyone in the same way. Right?'

emotionalTone: Philosophical, meta, some frustration (Gil, Alex), appreciation for process (Marc-Antoine, Ken), humor throughout

participationNotes.Jerry Michalski: Facilitator, tried to keep on frustrations before solutions, acknowledged OGM hasn't done much sense-making
participationNotes.Gil Friend: Challenged fundamental definitions - 'what do we mean by sense?', frustrated with conversation, doesn't come to OGM for sense-making
participationNotes.Mike Nelson: IETF model expertise, UN negotiation war stories, monastery beers quest
participationNotes.John Kelly: Collective intelligence continuum - breakthrough vs motherhood statements
participationNotes.Marc-Antoine Parent: Collective intelligence frameworks, negotiating meaning as the work, defended process orientation
participationNotes.Doug Breitbart: 'Collective' posits aggregate that doesn't exist, starts at Chapter 3 or 4 problem
participationNotes.Alex Kladitis: Solution-oriented, couldn't find thread, felt lost without objective, appreciated but didn't identify with discussion
participationNotes.Ken Homer: Expansive definitions story (Yosemite conflict workshop), closed with poem

specialNotes: Very meta call - sense-making about sense-making
Gil's challenge 'what do we mean by sense?' became central thread
Process vs outcomes tension: Marc-Antoine/Ken vs Alex/Mike
Alex: solution-oriented people can feel lost in process-oriented discussions
Jerry didn't even get to planned questions about evidence of sense-making
Humor: Should sense-making have a hyphen? Can we define 'good poem'?
Ken's Yosemite story exemplifies the call's own dynamic - expansive shared meaning
Call itself demonstrated the challenge it discussed

connectionsToOtherCalls.call03: Disinformation as frustration for sense-making - can't make sense when people actively preventing it
connectionsToOtherCalls.call04: Reality melting theme - if we can't agree on facts (Call 04), how do we make sense together (Call 05)?
connectionsToOtherCalls.call02: Check-in format vs topical - this call questioned OGM's value, similar to Kevin's trauma making participation hard

metaObservations.callDemonstratedItsOwnTheme: Discussion about sense-making illustrated exact problems: different definitions, process vs outcome orientation, frustration with lack of clarity
metaObservations.alexAsBarometer: Alex's feedback ('I was lost, looking for objective') represents audience who needs concrete outcomes vs process enjoyment
metaObservations.gilAsSkeptic: Gil's 'what do we mean by sense?' fundamental challenge - doesn't come to OGM for sense-making
metaObservations.marcAntoineAsDefender: Process itself is valuable - negotiating meaning, learning to think with others
metaObservations.unresolved: Call ended without resolving what sense-making is or whether OGM does it - perfect meta-illustration
